isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - New Vehicle Processing Manual - VEHICLE SAFETY CERTIFICATION - CERTIFICATION

svcprocinfo.para: It is important to remember that every vehicle manufactured for sale and sold for use in the United States or Canada must both comply with the applicable federal safety standards and must be certified that it does comply. This compliance may be accomplished as described below for complete and incomplete vehicles.

svcsubproc.title: Complete Vehicles - Certified at the Assembly Plant
svcsubproc.para: A complete vehicle is a unit which is deliverable and road-ready. International vehicles which are complete when shipped from the Assembly Plant are:

Certification is completed by installing a paper label permanently secured to either the hinge pillar, door-latch post, or the door edge that meets the door-latch post, next to the driver's seating position. The label is constructed of adhesive-backed paper which cannot be removed from the vehicle without being destroyed. The current labels for U.S. manufactured vehicles (1659611-C1) and for Canadian manufactured vehicles (1652154-C1) are shown below.
All vehicles produced for sale in Canada, including incomplete vehicles with supporting documents, must have the Canadian mark (436030-C1) installed.

important.para: Any party who replaces, adds, removes or modifies components on the vehicle that might affect the vehicle GAWR or GVWR (i.e., tires, springs, axles, etc.) must recertify the vehicle GAWR and GVWR.

svcsubproc.title: Incomplete Vehicles - Certified by the Final Stage Manufacturer
svcsubproc.para: An incomplete vehicle is a unit which leaves the Assembly Plant as a:

item.para: Flat back or windshield cowl chassis

svcsubproc.para: It is assumed that a body or other equipment will be mounted on the chassis by others prior to delivery of the vehicle to the end user. Such units are therefore classified as incomplete vehicles. It is obviously impossible for a flat back cowl chassis to comply with windshield glass standards, or for the chassis-cab to meet body lighting requirements. Therefore, these incomplete vehicles will be built with all appropriate safety items and will comply with the requirements of the law insofar as the vehicle state of completion permits. Incomplete vehicles shipped from the Assembly Plant are provided with a notification that the vehicle is incomplete. This notification is in the form of a 3- or 4-page document furnished with each incomplete vehicle containing the following information:

item.para: Name and mailing address of manufacturer
GAWR (Gross Axle Weight Rating) for each axle
Tire and rim choice with inflation pressure
List of all federal safety standards applicable to above type of vehicle. (Those standards already complied with as the vehicle is produced at the Assembly Plant will be identified.)

In all other vehicles, the incomplete vehicle document is placed in the left hand door dispatch compartment.

svcsubproc.title: Intermediate Manufacturer
svcsubproc.para: An Intermediate Manufacturer is a manufacturer, other than the Incomplete Vehicle Manufacturer or Final Stage Manufacturer, who performs manufacturing/assembly operations on an incomplete vehicle.

Modification to Incomplete Vehicles - If the Intermediate Manufacturer makes any changes in the vehicle which affect the validity of the statements in the incomplete vehicle document provided by International, that Intermediate Manufacturer must furnish an addendum to the incomplete vehicle document providing mailing address and an indication of all changes that should be made to the incomplete vehicle document to reflect changes made to the vehicle.
Chassis-Cabs built for sale in U.S. - In addition to furnishing the addendum above, each Intermediate Manufacturer must also affix an Intermediate Manufacturer Certification Label.

Intermediate Manufacturers should seek legal counsel to determine the type and wording of such certification when required. If it is determined that a International-supplied label will meet their needs, Intermediate Manufacturers may secure labels from International. Specify Part No. 501657C1 and protective cover Part No. 575023-C1 for use on chassis-cabs only.

svcsubproc.title: Final Stage Manufacturer
svcsubproc.para: Any party performing manufacturing/assembly operations to an incomplete vehicle and making it road-ready is considered the Final Stage Manufacturer. This includes any International facility, independent dealer, body builder, or equipment supplier. The party installing a body, equipment, a fifth wheel, etc. to complete the vehicle for delivery and make it road-ready is responsible to see that the complete vehicle meets all applicable safety standards, including certification.

The only exception is the situation where the end-user (owner) chooses to install his own body, specialized equipment, or fifth wheel on an incomplete vehicle. (Vehicles which are sold and delivered to end-users and which lack a body or other equipment necessary to make the vehicle complete and road-ready cannot be certified by the seller as a complete vehicle. A final certification label will not have been installed and all incomplete vehicle documents will have been left in the vehicle.) The owner is advised to retain these documents on file.

note.para: A chassis-cab intended for use as a tractor and built with all normal tractor equipment (trailer connections, lights, etc.) is not considered road-ready and complete until a fifth wheel has been installed.

svcsubproc.para: The Final Stage Manufacturer is responsible for installing an appropriate certification label, securely and permanently fixed to the complete vehicle. When acting as a Final Stage Manufacturer, International facilities should use a label as described under Section A for complete vehicles. The label is available to all Company retail outlets. For U.S. manufactured vehicles, use label 1659611-C1 ( Figure 20). For Canadian manufactured vehicles, use label 1652154-C1 ( Figure 21). Protective cover 435654-C1 must be installed over the label.

Any party other than a International facility who certifies a complete vehicle should seek legal counsel to determine the type of label construction, material and method of label attachment required as well as to determine the appropriate wording for the certification label to be installed. If it is determined that the type of label and wording of the label (shown in Figure 20) meets the needs of a Final Stage Manufacturer, a label may be obtained from International in which the name of the manufacturer is left blank by ordering label part number 436076-C3 ( Figure 26) and protective cover 435654-C1. svcsubproc.title: Modifications To Factory-Installed Items - Certified by Modifier
svcsubproc.para: If a complete vehicle is shipped from the Assembly Plant, but is subsequently modified, altered or added to by a party for further resale, the responsibility for compliance of the modified vehicle with the law rests with the party performing the modification, alteration, or addition. In such cases, the certification originally furnished by International with the vehicle must be supplemented by an additional certification by the party making the alteration. This certification should state:

This vehicle was altered by (name of modifier) in (month and year in which alterations were made) and as altered, it conforms to all applicable Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards affected by the alteration and in effect on the date of original manufacture.

This label ( Figure 28) is available under Part No. 449893-C4 for US vehicle alterers and Part No. 1676840C1 for Canadian vehicle alterers. Protective cover 435654-C1 should be installed over this label.

svcsubproc.title: Additional Certification Label Information And Instructions

step1.para: All labels must be fully filled out.
All labels must be affixed to the vehicle in accordance with FMVSR Parts 567.4, 568.5, 568.6, 568.7 and 568.8 or CMVSR, Sections 4 and 6.
No label shall be installed over another label.

It is unlawful to affix an incorrect certification label to a vehicle. NON-INTERNATIONAL MANUFACTURERS, INDEPENDENT DEALERS, BODY BUILDERS, EQUIPMENT SUPPLIERS, ETC. SHOULD NOT USE LABEL PART NUMBERS 1652150-C1, 1659607-C1, 1652154-C1 OR 1659611-C1.

INSTALLING IMPROPER CERTIFICATION LABELS CONSTITUTES A VIOLATION OF FEDERAL MOTOR VEHICLE SAFETY STANDARDS LAW. Any violation of this law is subject to a fine of up to $1,000 per vehicle with a maximum of $800,000 for a related series of violations. The requirements of the law are stringent and the penalties are severe. It is therefore extremely important that persons involved with installation of certification labels become fully familiar with the law as it relates to their responsibilities.

svcsubproc.title: Glider Kits - Certification Not Required
svcsubproc.para: Glider Kits are not considered vehicles by Federal Law. Glider Kits are a service part and assume the identity of the original vehicle being rebuilt. The rebuilt vehicle must then comply with the same Federal Law as the original vehicle. Local laws may involve additional regulations concerning glider kits. These laws may consider glider kits as other than service parts. Installers and users of glider kits must check with local authorities regarding licensing and other legal requirements.
